Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GEM: Modulation of Plasma Waves by Thermal Plasma Density Variation in the Inner Magnetosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Geospace Environment Modeling (GEM) Program is a broad-based, community-initiated research program on the physics of the Earth's magnetosphere and the coupling of the magnetosphere to the atmosphere and to the solar wind. The work of GEM is accomplished in a series of campaigns and focus groups that solve specific problems leading to the construction of a global Geospace General Circulation Model (GGCM) with predictive capability. This project will contribute essential results to this goal pertaining to understanding the role of plasma waves in energizing and transporting particles and plasma in the near-Earth space environment. In addition, the project supports the research of an early-career tenure-track faculty member and contributes to the research training of another early-career female scientist and a graduate student.

This investigation utilizes both spacecraft observations from THEMIS and Van Allen Probes and the HOTRAY wave ray-tracing computer code to study the modulation of plasma wave intensity by thermal plasma density variations in the inner magnetosphere. The specific science questions to be addressed include: (1) How do thermal plasma density variations cause modulation in the intensity of chorus, hiss and magnetosonic waves? and (2) How do the waves excited by these density variations affect radiation belt and ring current? The investigation is relevant to the GEM Focus Groups on "Storm-Time Inner Magnetosphere-Ionosphere Convection", and "Scientific Magnetic Mapping & Techniques".

Performance_Institution.Name: UT-Dallas, W. B. Hanson Center for Space Sciences

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, a unified observation-based and modeling investigation are used to understand the modulation of plasma wave intensity by thermal plasma density variations in the inner magnetosphere. Three different types of plasma waves investigated are plasmaspheric hiss, chorus, and magnetosonic waves, which play important roles in acceleration and loss of energetic electrons. Understanding the effects of thermal plasma density on redistributing the wave energy is important for modeling the coupling of energetic electrons and thermal plasmas in the collisionless magnetosphere.

This award leads to more than 25 publications in peer-reviewed journals (including 1 in Nature Communication). In addition, a book chapter is written to review how whistler mode waves and thermal plasma density control the global distribution of the diffuse aurora and the dynamical evolution of radiation belt electrons. Part of highlighted advancements on the effects of plasma density on the three waves are summarized below. The density gradients associated with the plasmapause enable cyclic paths for plasmaspheric hiss waves and therefore repeated amplification. The plasma density enhancement increases the intensity of both chorus waves and exohiss waves simultaneously by reducing the electron resonant energy and therefore increasing the number of resonant electrons. We also demonstrate that the variations of plasma parameters due to ultra low frequency (ULF) waves can leave significant impact on chorus waves by regulating the electron flux level and temperature anisotropy. Observationally the modulation of chorus and hiss intensity is often seen by satellite observation, while the interplay of magnetosonic wave intensity and plasma density is rarely seen, because the magnetosonic waves can propagate across field lines and therefore across the density variation. A fortunate observation from Van Allen Probes showing the modulation of magnetosonic waves by ULF waves is identified and presented. We also show observational evidence of magnetosonic waves being trapped by local density structures, supporting the previously proposed wave trapping theory. We also demonstrate that plasma density fine scale structures near the plasmapause can reflect the energy of magnetosonic waves, accounting for the observation that the magnetosonic waves often terminate at the plasmapause location.

This awarded project provides training for two young scientists, the PI and a female co-Investigator. The former became tenured associate professor in 2018 and the latter received prestigious American Geophysical Union (AGU) J. B. Macelwane Medal in 2017. The project also provides valuable support for two doctoral students under the supervision of the PI (one graduated in 2018 Summer and the other one to graduate in 2019 Summer). The results of this project have been made available to other members of the space physics community through conferences and publications. The PI has implemented part of findings to a new introductory Space Sciences course.
